awd_titl_txt: MCA: Quantitative understanding of heritable epigenetic changes
awd_abstract_narration:
Interactions with the environment in one generation of an organism can cause effects that last for many generations even without changes in DNA sequence. Being able to predict what genes will be affected in this way can enable a better understanding of hereditary diseases and suggest approaches for evaluating environmental exposures that can have lasting effects. By focusing on how single genes respond across generations in a model nematode, this project develops predictions for heritable change that can be tested using experimental measurements while involving undergraduate and graduate students in the research. Undergraduate students learn to represent and explore ideas through simulations. Graduate students learn to think, with simulations, about how to constrain possible inferences from their experiments before publishing their work. The enhanced quantitative reasoning imparted through the research and broader efforts prepares the upcoming workforce for an increasingly data-rich world. This award enables the PI, who is an experimentalist, to acquire expertise in modeling and theory development in biology.
 
This project is developing a unified theory of heritable epigenetic changes. It integrates experimental measurements with mathematical description and quantitative simulations by focusing on the changes that occur in the expression of single genes across generations in the nematode C. elegans. Since different sequence contexts prevent or promote heritable changes in RNA-mediated control of gene expression, the project measures differences in small RNAs, mRNAs, and other key regulators for six different contexts when the same coding sequence is targeted for RNA silencing. Quantitative measurements are used to constrain simulations that predict the nature and duration of transgenerational epigenetic change. In parallel, analytical descriptions of the regulatory relationships that can promote or hinder heritable epigenetic change are pursued to achieve deeper understanding.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Cases of epigenetic changes that arise without mutating DNA sequence and yet last for many generations are poised to transform our understanding of heredity. This award was for the mentored application of quantitative modeling and mathematical approaches to explain RNA-mediated heritable epigenetic changes observed using the nematode C. elegans and to engage early-stage researchers in the use of these approaches.

The systematic analysis of how molecules need to be regulated for heredity led to the enumeration of the simplest heritable regulatory architectures (Jose, eLife, 2024). Detailed analyses of these architectures (A through Z in attached figure) revealed the requirements for inducing heritable epigenetic changes. Such changes result in the ‘mutation’ of one regulatory architecture into another, providing a rich source of change and evolution without mutating in DNA sequence. Using the simplest of these architectures analytical expressions for epigenetic change were developed that provide quantitative predictions for the magnitude and duration of heritable epigenetic changes that can be tested using experiments. This framework also explains recent puzzling observations whereby genes can show susceptibility, recovery or resistance to induced epigenetic changes (Devanapally et al., Nat. Commun., 2021). For the same gene silenced for many generations, we detected diverse patterns of the key intermediate poly-UG RNAs, which serve as templates for the accumulation of antisense small RNAs. This discovery supports the idea that there are multiple forms of heritable epigenetic changes that can occur at a single gene (Chey et al., bioRxiv, 2024) as predicted by the multiple epigenetic ‘mutations’ that can alter most heritable regulatory architectures. The mentored training in mathematical modeling obtained through this award enabled its use to gain insights into RNA interference (Knudsen-Palmer et al., eLife, 2024) and to explain buffering of gene expression (Shugarts et al., eLife, 2024). Experiments inspired by these models led to the demonstration of the restricted production of poly-UG RNAs in somatic cells and that animals can recover from RNA interference in somatic cells despite the presence of mechanisms for amplifying the small RNAs used for gene silencing. Finally, since homeostasis is prevalent in living systems, we hypothesized that perturbations in regulators of RNA silencing could alter RNA levels of other regulators that encode proteins that interact with regulators of RNA silencing to restore the state before perturbation. This thinking led us to discover protein-protein interactions of regulatory importance by analyzing RNA sequencing data generated over the last 15 years in the field of RNA silencing (Lalit and Jose, bioRxiv, 2024).

Engaging graduate students and undergraduates in the research provided them with training in mathematical modeling, which is becoming increasingly important for the future workforce in biology. To address this need in graduate training, we developed a graduate course titled 'Quantitative Modeling for Experimental Biologists' that has been offered once and was received well. Students engaged in building models that answer questions about their own thesis projects, which is expected to accelerate their progress. To bring these approaches to undergraduate classrooms, more agent-based modeling for understanding difficult concepts like emergence were incorporated into an undergraduate course called 'Systems view of Cell Biology'. In this course teams of students learned coding and applied it to simulations that they created. Finally, we developed a First-Year Research and Innovation stream called 'Gene Silencing' which is providing the first hands-on research experience for ~30 undergraduate students each year. In this stream, students perform experimental work on heritable RNA silencing in C. elegans and explore quantitative models to refine their understanding.
